text: and with that I'd sort of like to tell you about some of this idea from my work which is on capturing human behavior and
language for interactive systems so as we all know computers are more and more integrated into society into our lives
yet they still don't understand many of the basic human actions that surround them so in this talk I'd like to explore
how we can teach computers to understand much more of this human context and also what new kinds of interactions we can
enable as a result so and if you think about it this is really a key component of many of these core ideas we've had in
human-computer interaction for example here's Mark Weiser the founder of ubiquitous computing and when Mark was
first motivating this idea he gives this example of a smart home that knows you might want to drink coffee after you
wake up now it's been decades since Mark first introduced this idea but how close are we really to systems that understand
these kinds of relationships today for example you know take an activity like packing now personally you know whenever
I'm going on a trip I always forget to bring my melatonin so I would love to be able to tell a system hey when I'm
packing remind me to bring my route melatonin but for this to work a system has to be able to really understand what
packing is and be able to identify it similarly there's many situations that
are more the inverse of this situations for example what you don't want to be interrupted by text messages or other
kinds of notifications for example if you're talking on the phone now on the other hand there plenty of situations
where this would be totally ok for example if you're sitting on the couch or taking your dog on a walk and so sort
of broadly by understanding the kind of human context that surrounds us interactive systems can start to make decisions that are more reasonable or
not reasonable similarly if we look at you know stuff in recent science fiction or maybe the kind of stuff envisioned by
Hollywood again we see systems that do things like play you upbeat music when you're sad or warn you when you're
leaving your home without your wallet and these systems are all very it's all understanding human behavior in a much
broader sense then systems tend to do today so today we have these systems
that do a really good job of understanding facts about the world we have these massively crowd-sourced knowledge bases systems like concept net
that could tell us relationships like water is a liquid we also have these really great machine learning models
techniques like semantic parsing which can learn from large data to answer questions like who's the president dr.
Barack Obama but if we think about these motivating questions things like understanding what happens after we wake
up or the fact that we're in a meeting maybe means we're busy and so we want to ignore a phone call systems just don't
tend to capture these kinds of relationships today so what I'd like to suggest in this talk is that to really
make progress on these visions proposed by wiser and others what we need are systems that much more deeply understand
people systems that really capture the breath of human experience so just to
make this design goal a bit more explicit what I'm really talking about here are systems that capture an enormous number of human activities so
there are thousands of activities that occur in daily life things like waking up drinking coffee using a computer going running imagine anything you do in
a course of a day we want systems that understand each of those things and it's important to note here that this is kind
of broadening out the reach of existing work for example in context we're computing where people do a good job of
modeling a handful of activities or similarly work that looks at modeling a large number of activities but within a
narrow domain for example modeling sequences of commands in Photoshop to predict what kind of command someone
might want to execute next so we want to sort of expand these ideas to encompass the full breadth of human life now the
obvious challenge you run into here those you know where does this information come from how do we capture these thousands of
human behaviors in the relationships between them and then how do we model those for use in our active systems so
let's call that first challenge the sort of system model and let's even say we can make progress on that challenge
there's still a second challenge I want to motivate today and to do this I'd like to sort of step back and sort of give a bigger picture of how users
interact with systems so you have a system and you have an API or a kind of interface that that system presents but
just as critically you have this idea of a user model or how our user conceptualizes interactions with a system and what's really important here
is that when there's a mismatch between how a user understands a system and how a system actually works you can often
run into these big problems so it's not just enough to be able to capture and model this kind of information we also
have to focus on how people can use it and how we can make these models interpretable to the users and system designers you might want to make use of
them so in the second part of the talk I'm going to explore this more through how we can allow computational social scientists
this particular subgroup of users to apply these kinds of models to enable new kinds of text analysis so that
brings me to the outline of the talk in the first part of the talk I'll sort of talk about the system auger which mines these thousands of behaviors in human
life the relationships between these behaviors and exposes them to interactive systems and then in the second part of the talk I'll focus on
more how people can use and interpret these models and in particular how computational social scientists can use
these models to enable new kinds of text analysis so with that let's move into auger and sort of just to provide a kind
of baseline for the kinds of predictions we want to make here here's you know an example of a piece of context that a
interactive system might want to act upon for example Facebook it might benefit from knowing that if you're
around Facebook you might do something like getting a message or opening or closing your laptop similarly if you're
around if you're if it knows you're taking a shower maybe it can then predict that you want to change your clothes or brush your teeth or if you've
just ordered coffee maybe it should be able to predict that maybe you're gonna take a sip of the coffee or you're gonna pay for the coffee or if you're around a
stove a pot and a spoon maybe you're gonna do something like cook or stir the pot so these are kind of baseline of the
kind of information we want to capture in the system but again we're left with this question which is just you know how
do we actually capture this information we can't just sort of manually sit down and encode these thousands of behaviors
into the system much less the interactions between them so we need some kind of data from which we can mine these things but what does that data
actually look like well what you might want or probably don't want is this sort of dystopian world where cameras are
monitoring everyone 24/7 you can trace all these user activities right well not a data set we have also probably not a
data set we want alternatively you could you know look at stuff like social media a different kind of dystopia sometimes
you know people post things there all the time things like I'm running a marathon you know I'm getting into a new
relationship but these things just don't quite occur at like right the quite the right level of abstraction so for
example people don't post things like you know I'm typing on my keyboard then I'm standing up then I'm walking to my window right we don't get this sort of
prosaic or mundane information about the glue of human life so really the
fundamental idea in this work is what we use fiction to model this idea of human behavior what if we use fiction to
capture these many relationships between human activities and the context that surrounds them so fiction has these really two great
advantages first it's built on narrative so characters do things to interact in the world and there's a particular
ordering or Association of these things that they do and the second advantage is that it has this really rich set of
scene context so there are many places objects even adjectives that surround characters when they're taking certain
kinds of actions and we can kind of combine this together to build these broad models of human life so we want to
use fiction but what specific data are we actually interested in here well the data we used was a specific data from
the Wattpad writing community and the main property of this data is that it's modern fiction so these are stories set
in the modern world they're not sort of like in fantasy places on spaceships right we want to be able to model things
that people are doing in the world so we want sort of fiction set in the present day and similarly this is a very large
corpus more than 2 billion words and as you can imagine when you want to do this sort of broad data mining a lot of data
helps you quite a lot here so just to kind of motivate how this technique button technique might work I'm going to
give you a simple sentence so he walked to the bookshelf picked up his favorite book and started to read and even in
this simple sentence we can start to see you know how you can build associations between activities so for example you
know picking up a book is perhaps associated with reading and similarly we can see how you know context terms are
surrounded by these activities so perhaps around a bookshelf you're gonna do things like you know picking up a book or reading and so we can combine
you know this insight together to create what's called the augur knowledge base so the first thing in here is you know
obviously this idea of human activities so what do we mean by this well literally a thing that a person does so
a verb phrase with a human subject so we can extract these things through subject verb object parses your drop articles
and modifiers lemma ties these things to collapse the vocabulary and we end up with more than 50,000 of them things
like opening a refrigerator or turning off the lights or going to the gym and then the second thing in the knowledge
base is this idea of context or this idea of objects locations and adjectives that surround characters when they're
taking certain kinds of actions so here we have more than 10,000 of these in the knowledge base as well these are things
like beaches shirts cars or houses and so we put these two things together to enable these two main
api's the first is an API that takes a set of scene context and predicts an activity so for example given context
like plate fork and table I may predict an activity like eating and the second thing is an act as an API that takes one
activity or a set of activities and then predicts an Associated activity so for example associated with ordering and
eating we might have an activity like paying so that's how the knowledgebase
looks but how do we actually get here how do you actually model the fiction to create these kinds of api's well so
here's the pipeline what happens is we start with a fiction we run it through the parsing step so we extract these
subject-verb-object parses these pieces of context we then pass these to our neural network where the ideas we're
trying to predict relationships between words in a sliding window and I'll say more about that in a bit we can use this neural network to then build a vector
space which gives us a representation of these high-level activities as well as the context terms and then we can query
that vector space to enable the two api's that I just talked about so this neural network what is this
thing actually doing well again the high-level idea here is we want to predict words within a sliding window to
build a representation of activities and the context words so effectively by
having neural networks make these predictions we build up a sort of meaning a representation in the hidden layer of the network that provides a
vector space representation so if you've seen models like the continuous skip Graham model more commonly known as word
Tyvek this is a very similar idea but we're extending this to operate on the high-level idea of activities as well as
the low-level idea of words or context
so just to be very concrete about how this works here's the set of sequence data and the kind of prediction tasks
that we give to the network so we have a window it slides over the data we have a target word for example you're cold and
then we try to predict you know other words or activities within the window things like day and walk home and then
we slide the window down create a new target word now we our target as day and we predict cold walk home and eat lunch
we slide it down again we make these thousands even millions of predictions all over the data to build up this sort
of hidden layer representation and again the high-level idea here is we're building up a representation of these
activities in context that we can then use for these downstream berries so here's concretely what the
network looks like again is probably familiar to you if you've seen these kinds of networks before again what we're doing here is we're extending the
input vocabulary to contain the high level activities as well as the context words again then that's past the hidden
layer we make these predictions about other words in the space and then we sort of build up a meaning over time and
so what we can do then is you know take this meaning that we've built up in the hidden layer and convert that into a
representation for everything in the vocabulary so effectively we have a matrix here where we can index in on
that matrix to get a representation for different words and activities in the space so for example an activity like
eat home or eat food would then you know have a vector representation that we could use for these downstream tasks and
so a vector space is useful here because it provides this sort of natural sense of similarity or relationship between
different things in the space so for example if I have a vector space then I inject a piece of context context like
lunch I can just look in that space and see what kinds of activities are closer in the space and what activities are
further away so for example activities like eating and cooking might be closer in the space whereas activities like
hailing a cab or driving or further away in this space and we can formalize this through measures like cosine similarity
distance measures over vectors which you know give you things like you know table and eating has relatively high cosine
similarity table and pet dog would have relatively lower cosine similarity and the other nice property here is that we
can query on multiple examples through this nice property of vector addition right so if we want to combine multiple pieces of context for a query we just
sum of those vectors together run that against all the other activities in the space using cosine similarity then can
compute a ranked list of the associated activities so this gives us stuff like this if we're around a plate a steak in
a fork we can make predictions like maybe we're filling the plate or we're eating food if we round a bench maybe
we're making predictions like sitting if we're around or if we give an activity like waking up maybe we want breakfast
or we want to check the clock if we're taking a selfie maybe we want to take or upload a photo so that's the kind of
prediction that we can enable through this system but what kinds of applications can we actually build on top of those models so I mentioned
earlier in the talk this idea of sort of a phone that's reacting to the context around you so can all go do something
like this well we can take an activity like get call and look at the answer set returned by the vector space we see things like
answering call calling back ignoring the call and now we can start to combine this with other kinds of context and see
how these sort of relationships change so when we add in something like cursing to this vector we now see that ignore
call moves higher in the list than answer call we also see new things enter the list things like throwing phone which reflects the dramatic bias of
fiction which will say a little bit more about in a second but also are in their own right useful things that interactive
systems might be able to leverage similarly at the beginning I gave this example packing right so it can all go
do something like this well given context like for example a shirt shoes in a suitcase we can look at
sort of what are associated activities in the space and we see things yes in fact like packing also like wearing
clothes or putting on shoes so again we didn't have to sort of manually predefined all of the different things
that might lead to packing the sort of natural relationships that fall out of this vector space sort of give us that
information for free again maybe there's a another example where I've been
spending too much money recently and I want a notification a sort of text message whenever Auger thinks I'm going to spend more money sort of to prevent
me from doing this so there's a number of activities that might result in a future activity or an associated
activity of spending money for example entering the store perhaps you're likely to pay for something but it's really
quite a diverse set of activities here so for example when you enter or call a taxi this is also an activity that's
likely to result in a pay action and again we didn't have to sort of pre encode all of these different activities that might be associated with paying we
sort of get these out of the relationships in the space okay so that's a kind of illustration of what
kinds of applications we can build but how do we actually embed this system into the world right how do we actually get this signal about sort of you know
what are these pieces of context that surround us so to do this we can add a new layer to the pipeline a sort of computer vision layer taking
off-the-shelf computer vision processing some images to produce context terms then pass those terms to the API to make
these activity predictions which then these interactive systems can begin to react to so the basic way this works is
you have a picture you take some CV context out of the picture so your computer vision tells us like this
picture has people mountain tree and backpack we can then pass these to the augur API and we see things like hike
or reaching the top or another picture of beach scene we can pass this to auger
and we see things like laying a towel or diving and we actually built this out
into what we call the dynamic music player so we took a Google glass I'll sort of had it take continuous pictures
over the scene of those pictures past the auger API identified sort of activities that it could and then pass
those back to play different kinds of music so we were looking at seven activities in particular walking working
sitting eating driving buying and reading and we just sort of wanted to see you know how well could the system do in practice that identifying this
sort of basic set of activities you get given the context that we were able to get get from these images and so just to
give you a few examples of the frames here here's a picture in the car right so of course we can predict that were
driving and here's a picture in the library and of course we can predict that we are reading and so we computed a
precision and recall across all the activities in the system over these frames and so what we found was that
recall tended to be quite a bit higher than precision so the system was relatively good at identifying an activity when it was happening but there
were quite a few more false positives right which lower the precision a little bit so what this sort of suggests is
that when you're designing for these kinds of applications you should be focused on more recall oriented systems or at least systems that can tolerate
this low precision so for example if I'm building a food diary that takes a picture automatically when it thinks I'm
eating you know false positive there isn't going to be the end of the world on the other hand if I'm having a self-driving car react to some positive
prediction you know that could be a very big deal right so these are the kind of designs constraints to be keeping in
mind here so it's sort of stepping back a bit what I want to sort of really get
across here is that this is opening a new design space which gives you these sort of two main abilities the first is
the ability to react to current activities right so this is expressed through things like well if I'm eating
food I want you to take a picture for my food diary or combining different sort of present signals things like oh if I'm
getting a call and then I'm cursing maybe we're gonna silence the phone or if I'm cooking bringing up a recipe application and then the second thing we
get here is this idea of proactivity on future or associated activities so for example if I'm calling a suitcase and
Aughra can say that while getting a suitcase is something that's likely to follow that and the we have another piece of signal that says the suitcase is not with me maybe
we can say oh you don't have your suitcase give you a warning about that or if I'm entering a store maybe we can
predict that I'm going to pay for something and so it's send me a text message that gives me my bank balance information or if I'm buying food maybe
we can predict that I'm going to cook later and so sort of remind me what ingredients that I need so we sort of
open up these two broad design spaces here so with that I'd like to move a
little bit into more of a formal technical evaluation because with these kinds of systems you can sort of evaluate and see you know how these
applications work but it's also important to have benchmarks that you can use to continue to improve these models we serve benchmarks that other
people can use to build similar models and improve on what you're doing so in this case what we're gonna do is
crowdsource a sort of gold standard set of labels basically replicating the kinds of tasks we're asking this if the
system to do in practice so here for example giving you know proud workers a set of context terms and then asking
them to predict what kinds of activities will occur around those terms but if we can do the same thing for giving the
crowd workers activities and then asking them to tell you what activities are gonna be associated with those activities and so what we get here is
the sort of data set that looks something like this here's a few examples if you give a crowd something like clock countdown in television
they'll tell you well things like watching TV you're celebrating or checking the time those are the kinds of
things that will happen or if you ask the crowd what happens you know with opening a folder and reading a paper they'll say oh maybe closing the folder
or organizing or starting work and now that we have this sort of ground truth data set we can go through and actually
see you know how well does the model do it distinguishing these things from the other stuff in the space so we can
compute some numbers here using a UC or AU ROC the nice thing about this is that sort of aggregates over all the
different to positive rates we have a baseline rate of 50 percent so if the model is not doing anything it's going to be a 50 percent we also included a
sort of you know baseline naive model based on co-occurrence accounts so you know what happens if you just sort of
take activity context relationships and build a sort of naive vector space using co-occurrence statistics you can see
that does a little bit better than the random model but not as good as a neural network you can also see that sort of as
we increase the size of the hidden layer in the neural network the performance goes up but it's sort of asymptotes over time
I think it's important to point out here that you know while these numbers look relatively good they don't represent performance on a real-world task these
are simply benchmarks that you can use to sort of you know evaluate and continue to improve the models here so
the second kind of formal evaluation we really wanted to do was attack this idea more directly of dramatic bias and
fiction right so in fiction if I enter a room it's perhaps far more likely I'm going to go and punch someone than it is
in reality right so you know to what extent is as a problem in our data and sort of how can we start to evaluate
this so the basic idea we had was that again we can use crowdsourcing to construct a data set of a human prior
over you know what's likely to happen around different kinds of contexts or different kinds of objects so we can ask
people effectively you know if we have a chair you know what are what is the likelihood that this set of activities
is going to happen around a chair is it more likely that I'm going to sit in the chair that I'm gonna throw the chair that I'm going to pull up the chair right so we can sort of get the sort of
distribution of likelihood over these related activities and then what we can do is compare the distribution produced
by the system to the distribution produced by the humans and sort of see what kinds of bias crop up so when we do
this in practice we do see a significant difference between the system and the people it wasn't quite as big as we were
expecting and actually when we sort of dig into it a little bit we see that the vast majority of this difference comes
from these super mundane activities like seeing so the system says you're far
more likely to see a chair so people see a chair in fiction all of the time whereas if you ask Youmans you know are
you more likely to see a chair or sit in a chair they'll actually say they're more likely to sit in a chair all right so there's sort of an ambiguity here or
perhaps a human bias that's kind of affecting this a little bit as well of course we did also see some of this
dramatic bias that we were expecting and in here it sort of took more often the romantic turn so again because this is
modern fiction sort of set in the modern world and we filtered for that a lot of these stories were romance stories right
so if you have these kinds of interpersonal interactions these are far more likely to result in things like kissing then you might have in the real
world okay so with that I really just sort of hope I've sort of convinced you that
text fiction really can teach computers the surprisingly broad and accurate models of the world right so these
models aren't necessarily going to be driving your self-driving car tomorrow but they do provide useful priors that we can use to start build
new kinds of interactive systems and so with that I'd like to move into the second part of my talk so in this part
of the talk I'm gonna focus a little bit more on this idea of interpretability or or usability of these models and how
other kinds of groups can use and introspect them and in particular how we can use similar kinds of models to allow
computational social scientists to do new kinds of text analysis and this is a
system called empath so as I've kind of just been talking about today we have all of these really
powerful language models we have these word embeddings they give you this like really rich idea of connotation we have
these great supervised learning models things like convolutional neural networks recurrent neural networks we have this great unsupervised topic
modeling and then sort of on the other side of the world we have all this stuff that's going on in computational social science so people are doing things like
you tracking the spread of emotions on Facebook looking at sort of you know what words indicate on lying or telling
the truth even trying to figure out what words indicate that I'm gonna betray you and if you think about it you might expect
that people are often leveraging these powerful language models to engage in this kind of work but if you go out and look in the space I think you'll find
that this is you know surprisingly often not the case and the reason I'd like to give in this talk for this is that
computational social sciences strongly value interpretability in their models right so you know when they report in
effect they want to be able to very specifically point to where did that effect come from and so what this means
is that people very often use what are called rule-based models models that have a small number of very easily
interpretable rules so things like decision trees or inclusion exclusion properties for words and again the goal
here is that you know people are able to inspect these models with very limited technical sophistication so a very
common kind of model that people use here is what's called a lexicon a category that sort of is represented by
a list of words so for example if I want to measure anger and text I have this word list contains words like scream war
mad and so on and I sort of use that word list to analyze the text across the categories I'm interested in so there
have been many of these tools created over the years very extensively validated probably the most popular of
which is called Luke linguistic in Korean word count this thing has been used for hundreds or thousands of studies been very impactful and again
how these things work is you have a piece of text you walk over the text you count the words that fall into the
given category that you're interested in you can then take normalized counts over those categories and then compare those
counts across populations of documents to compute some kind of statistic so if
you just sort of think about this you start to run into some obvious questions right so the first question is well what
about breath right what if I want to analyze a category that doesn't exist in any lexicon today for example a category
like violence or like social media right these are things that don't exist in Luke similarly what about words that
don't exist in these categories right so these categories are updated very infrequently once every few years few years or so and so you end up with
you know categoric Bitcoin not appearing in Luke's money category for example so
the idea that we're presenting in this work is that we'd like to take this very powerful and useful conceptual model
provided by lexicons that computational social scientists use today and combine this with the power of these more
sophisticated language models I didn't sort of get the best of both of this both of these techniques so what we
did was we came up with a tool called empath and what this tool allows you to do is generate new categories from a set
of seed words so for example if I have if I want to analyze categories called
social media I can choose to seed words that sort of best approximate that category words like for example Twitter
and Facebook I can then use empath to generate a set of words basically a word list that I can use to analyze that
category and then go and apply that category to the text and again we can use the sort of standard ideas from cosine similarity and other kinds of
natural language processing to create these kinds of word lists and what we can also do because it's so easy to
generate these things is create a much broader set of hundreds of predefined categories that people can use for their
analyses today so these are categories like technology violence government strength all of these things that don't
exist in lexicons like Luke and again the idea here is that we want to maintain interpretability while
increasing the breadth in terms of the number of categories that people are able to analyze as well as the flexibility basically allowing people to
generate these new categories on demand now the question you run into though is
well how well do these language models actually replicate the psychrometric Lee validated word lists right in some cases
literally teams of psychologists sat down in a room and created these word lists so how well can these machine generated lexicons
actually performing comparison to these things well the first thing you want to do in this case is kind of create a baseline or a benchmark and so what you
can do is you can take correlations between the signals reported by existing similar human generated lexicons so I've
already talked about Luke there's other lexicons like the general and fire and like emo Lex we can compare the signals
reported by similar categories in each of these tools and get Pearson correlations and what we end up with this stuff like you know point eight
nine point eight seven and now what we can do is generate our machine generated lexicons and see how well those compare
in comparison so here the actual processes you have a set of training text you choose some words on that
training text that best approximate the category you're interested in then you apply that category on the held-out test
text and then you compute a Pearson correlation over all these counts that you produce and so what we end up with
here is that we have a correlation on average of 0.9 over the categories we compare it against with Luke and this
compares very favorably against the sort of Pearson correlations taken between the existing human generated lexicons so
we can actually even push this one step further and look at can we actually replicate some existing high-impact work
in the space so for example in 2011 Golder and macy published this study looking at mood on twitter over time of
day and so what they found was sort of as the day goes on you have this sort of increase in negative effect on Twitter where you have this sort of peak and
decline of the positive effect and so what we're able to do is sort of you know replicate those signals using the Luke tool and then show how the
categories and empath also replicate nearly exactly the same signals again with this sort of very high correlation
and so the take-home point here is that really these unsupervised language models really can capture many of the
same signals as the psychometrically validated word lists right these models capture many of the dimensions that
humans are using when they construct these word lists in the first place so I mentioned that empath has a number of
other predefined categories so how do we actually get these things well the basic idea was we bootstrap them off of
relationships and existing knowledge basis so I mentioned concept not earlier in the talk this thing contains element
of relationships like shirts and hats or elements of clothing we can effectively look at those relationships and use them
to bootstrap a new set of categories in empath and so what we end up with is you know pretty large set of categories
things like journalism Envy music communication programming even stuff like hipster and here's what some
of these look like so for violence you have injure fight bleed hipster iconic
stylish retro technology robot browser
binary pretty diverse set of stuff and so what we did was we took this and we
sort of put it out in various different ways we have a website where people can go and generate new categories to use
for their text analysis we also have a Python tool that people can download and use to either generate new categories or
analyze text and this has been picked up and used by a number of external researchers so people have used it for
example to characterize hateful speech on Twitter to look at linguistic trends as communities grow over time or even to
look at linguistic differences between effective and non effective team structures and this work has been published in pretty respectable venues
venues like IC WSM or chi oh sorry ok yeah guy it also it's in use by Facebook
data science so now actually what I want to do is show you how you can use this tool to extend some existing work in
computational social science well I'm actually going to kill two birds with one stone here and show you this demo
through another tool that I've just published in Chi 2018 called iris this is a conversational agent that allows

back but what I think we can do better here I'm gonna actually just plot these things to give you a better sense of it
so I reference the previous thing that we just did with that keyword now I'm gonna choose a column with the labels
